sections.title: Description
sections.raw_content: The not (boolean negation) operator produces the opposite of a true/false value. For example, not (x >y) is equivalent to x <= y.
sections.text_content: The not (boolean negation) operator produces the opposite of a true/false value. For example, not (x >y) is equivalent to x <= y.
sections.mdown_content: The **not** (*boolean negation*) operator produces the opposite of a true/false value. For example, **not** (*x *>*y*) is equivalent to *x* <= *y*.

sections.title: Example
code:
var error : boolean := false
        var success : boolean
        Â…
        success := not error    % success becomes the opposite of error

sections.title: Details
sections.raw_content:
The not operator takes true and produces false and takes false and produces true. The not operator can be written as ~. See also the boolean type, prefix operators, and precedence of operators.

The not operator can be applied to sets.
sections.text_content:
The not operator takes true and produces false and takes false and produces true. The not operator can be written as ~. See also the boolean type, prefix operators, and precedence of operators.
The not operator can be applied to sets.
sections.mdown_content:
The **not** operator takes **true** and produces **false** and takes **false** and produces **true**. The **not** operator can be written as ~. See also the **boolean** type, *prefix operators*, and *precedence *of operators.
The **not** operator can be applied to sets.
